Fields.DialogueText: We're making excellent time to the Mediterranean, Kapitan.
Thank you, Chervona. How is everyone holding up?
As good as they can, considering the circumstances.

Fields.MenuText: The morality of our mission is hardly black and white, Chervona, but we will follow orders.
Understandable. It is an unorthodox mission.
Circumstances?

Fields.DialogueText: You say gray. I say foul and cowardly.
Unorthodox, yes. Illegal, possibly. Deplorable, absolutely.
Don't play stupid, Kapitan. It doesn't suit you.
Chervona, this is just a meeting, arranged by the Protection Force. Why are you so upset?
Because I, a Belle, daughter of Ukraine, am to be hostess to pirates.
Don't exaggerate, Chervona. We're not laying out the fine china.
*ALARM*
Nor would I if I indulged in such things. Morganas, Kapitan; fast approach.
Bring us around!
@BATTLE
The Morganas are a global threat. We need all the help we can get.
Pirates, Kapitan! Scourge of honest and defenseless folk. Would you let a fox into your chicken coop because you heard a wolf was about?
Chervona? What are you doing in inventory?
Increasing security, Kapitan. These locks are... inadequate.
Listen, I don't look forward to meeting with these pirates any more than you do. But must you be so... severe?
I hate no one, but I am no fool. They are professionals of greed and violence.

Fields.MenuText: It might not be that simple. People tend to be more complicated than that.
You're judging people you haven't met.
You hate no one? Had me fooled.

Fields.DialogueText: Actions are simple. The complications grow around them like weeds.
No, Kapitan, they may be sweet little dumplings that love their mothers. I judge their line of work.
You mistake my passion for malice.
I see your point, Chervona. But I need to know you won't instigate anything when they're on board.
No, I will not.
It's just that you have a lot to say that may offend...
I gave you my word. I will not.
*ALARM*
Let's go.
Yes, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
You're sure this is the rendezvous location?
It is the location we were sent.
Where could they be?
*ALARM*
Could that be our answer? Or a trap?
I hope not. Prepare to engage.
@BATTLE
If Morganas got to them, this mission is a waste.
It's unlikely they were destroyed. They have pirated these waters for years. They know how to survive.

Fields.MenuText: Was that a compliment? A pirate compliment?
I hope you're right.
Being clever doesn't always save you out here.

Fields.DialogueText: It was. I never implied they were incompetent. Only predatory.
Will you seek them out?
Regrettably so.
We will keep an eye on the rendezvous area and see if we can't find any sign of them.
As you command.
More smoke, another burning life raft, and no sign of the pirates. When does it end?
When they run out of rafts to steal, Kapitan.
I think you've made your point.
*ALARM*
Morganas, Kapitan, right on schedule.
I'm losing what faith I had in these pirates.
@BATTLE
Clearly, the pirates are in the area. Why not attempt to contact us for aid?
I think we are missing something, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: What?
Do you think someone else is setting the fires?
What do you suggest?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know. But this simply doesn't add up.
Preposterous. Nobody swims out this way for the sake of a prank.
We continue our pursuit until we have better information.
We'll continue on with the mission, then.
As a gambler despairs of winning back their earnings.
It's a poor pirate that sacrifices a means of escape. Whatever they're doing, they must be desperate. That bodes well for us.
Chervona, they're not our enemy.
They are the enemy of the people, Kapitan. I am an embodiment of the people's will. That makes them my enemy.
Unless Stalin himself orders no quarter, we're to at least talk to them.
In a perfect world we would bring them to justice.
This isn't what I'd call a perfect world.
Not yet, Kapitan. Not yet.
Well.
A burning raft, no pirates, and curious Morganas. That's thrice now.
We're either doing something very right or very wrong.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, I have a theory.
Lay it on me, Chervona.
The location of the three fires... they form a triangle.
And the center of the three points is the rendezvous point?
Yes. The pirates correctly surmised that the Morganas would be drawn to the fires. I'm guessing they're using the fires to lead the Morganas away from the rendezvous point.
So we were never meant to meet at the fires to begin with.
It would appear so.

Fields.MenuText: How do we know when to meet at the center?
Great work, Chervona!
What if this is all an elaborate ploy?

Fields.DialogueText: I assume they will continue to use fires to lead the Morganas further away. We, however, should stay close to the rendezvous point. The pirates will arrive eventually.
Think nothing of it. I simply asked myself how I would solve a problem in the least helpful possible way.
Then they should reveal themselves soon. The seas are no place for patience right now.
Then let's head for the center.
If you'll forgive me, Kapitan, I should like to see to the crew. A few of them are...restive.
Mutinous?
Frustrated. Some of them are questioning the mission's value. Which is something I can relate to.
Can I trust you to keep their spirits up?
I am sworn to them, Kapitan, but I am also sworn to you. As personally distasteful as I find this misson, I'll make sure we're united in its success.
I appreciate your honesty, Chervona.
Duty, Kapitan, to you and to my crew. Nothing more.
You know, Chervona - for as much as you disapprove of these pirates, you don't have much difficulty thinking like them.
They are capable and clever, even if they stand against everything I do.
And what do you stand for?
Do you often pry into personal matters?

Fields.MenuText: I didn't know I was being overly personal. Never mind.
Yes, I do. Does that make you uncomfortable?
No, I don't. So?

Fields.DialogueText: You were not. Sorry, I was overly sensitive.
No, Kapitan. Just surprised.
You are... confusing, Kapitan. But, I suppose, so can I be.
So what bothers you? The stealing? The pillaging?
They take and hoard. I have problems with all who value coin over starving families.
I see.
*ALARM*
The Morganas are a threat to your way of life, Kapitan. I recognize that. But I would hate to see you compromise yourself in the name of victory.
Never thought a warship would set me to soul-searching before a fight.
@BATTLE
Who better?
There, another fire! I can just see its smoke on the horizon.
And the usual complement of Morganas. Say what you will about the pirates - their plan's certainly worked.
Just our luck. Let's finish them quickly.
@BATTLE
Approaching the rendezvous point.

Fields.MenuText: They'll be there. They have to be.
I hope you're right, Chervona.
What if we are wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: Hope for the best. Plan for the worst.
As do I, Kapitan. Hope may have to come in handy.
Then they won't be here, and we are free to report failure in the name of a greater good.
There! That ship, it has to be them.
How can you tell?
They're flying a jolly roger.
Ridiculous. This ought to please the crew, at least.
How are they holding up?
Better. I reassured them that our cause was just and we would stand firm against the true enemy.
I've been trying to do that this whole tour.
You've been pulling rank this whole tour, Kapitan. The sailors signed up for this, but they need to know that the world will be better for it.
Some of them are just here because it's a job, you know.
Da. But you need not embark on your journey with a cause. Sometimes you find one along the way.
Even if you're a pirate?
Sometimes there is no zealot like the recent convert. World revolution comes to us at different times. And it is coming. Our crew at least will be ready.
Captain Inna, welcome aboard. This is the ship's Belle, Chervona.
Pleasure.
Chervona? Ha! Another Ukranian. Pry'vit, sestra.
Do not exclude others with our language, Kapitan Inna.
I would not dream of doing so. I've heard of the mixed crews aboard these Protection Force ships.

Fields.MenuText: No need to apologize.
Thank you.
Chervona, please.

Fields.DialogueText: Da. The kapitan can handle unsavory company.
Go on, Kapitan Inna.
Of course, Kapitan.
*ALARM*
Morganas! Captain, we have much to discuss after fending them off.
Go for it. We'll sit back and see what you can do.
@BATTLE
Safe in their beds while we do the heavy lifting.
Safe in their cells. It's a compromise.
There can be no compromise in revolution.
You want us to act as privateers? You must be joking. Privateers have not existed for decades!
For good reason.
I assure you, this is a legitimate offer. In return for your help against the Morganas, you will be offered amnesty.
Amnesty, aye? I do like the sound of that.
Amnesty for past crimes, not your future exploitation.

Fields.MenuText: Chervona could be less blunt, but she is right. The amnesty would not be granted for any future crimes.
Just as she said.
Chervona, let me handle this, thank you.

Fields.DialogueText: So don't even think about it.
The piracy ends, or you do.
Of course, Kapitan.
*ALARM*
Well, I've much to mull over. I'll find myself a drink - you can handle the Morganas, I trust?
Of course, make yourself... at home.
@BATTLE
I'll give her something to mull.
Unless it's mead, don't bother.
Nikoly. That is for the crew and for me. If she proves false, it will stay that way.
Kapitan, my patience has its limits.
I hear you, Chervona. Captain Inna and her crew are... abrasive.
The gluttons drink and play while we protect them from Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Captain Inna said she will have an answer for us soon.
She has a time limit. We won't be here forever.
We have our orders, Chervona.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, she says many things. She does few.
They are abusing your generosity, Kapitan.
Da. And I have my reservations.
*ALARM*
Captain Inna, care to join us in defending our ships? Captain Inna, report.
Weeds in the garden...
@BATTLE
Captain, I have come to a decision.
I'm in suspense.
You will join us at our base of operations. We need help.

Fields.MenuText: So are you accepting your commission?
You misunderstand, Captain Inna. We are not at your disposal.
Are you giving orders to me?

Fields.DialogueText: Not yet, Captain. I have a bargain.
I thought this was a negotiation.
Making suggestions. They might just save lives. Make of them what you will.
I don't think you're in any position to negotiate. Last I checked, I have a ship and you don't.
Full disclosure: my fleet is in turmoil. The Morganas have been more than a match. If you help me secure my home and family, we will accept the commission.
*ALARM*
Very well. Go. Leave the coordinates with me before these Morganas are upon us.
Aye-aye! Haha. No, good luck. Thank you, Chervona. You were a lovely host.
My loveliness has limits.
@BATTLE
You've sure changed your tune.
I have not. I've watched her during this tour, Kapitan. Her men are louts and she's queen lout of the pack.
But?
But they are a family. That I can respect. If they know what it is to be a part of something greater, perhaps they aren't totally hopeless.
Now then. It's time I served as an example to my family.
Are we on course to Captain Inna's home?
We are.
So...

Fields.MenuText: What is your opinion on the deal?
You think we shouldn't help them?
You survived being hostess.

Fields.DialogueText: Guarded optimism, Kapitan.
I'm conflicted, Kapitan.
I did, but I don't feel I am better for it.
The Morganas are the enemy of mankind. We all have to help one another in this fight.
Foxes and wolves. We have had this conversation before, Kapitan. I am tentatively willing to see how a wolf defends her pack, now that I know she has one.
*ALARM*
Morganas? There seem to be more here than reports indicated.
Reports can only get one so far with these witches.
@BATTLE
This is the pirates' hideout? Where are they?
We wait.
Wonderful.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: This is a terrible hideout.
Why would the Morganas have any interest in this place?
Where is Captain Inna?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know... it's pretty secluded. In fact, I'm surprised the Morganas found it.
Maybe they don't like pirates any more than I do.
Maybe she left us a message?
Outfit some of the crew and have them search the buildings for a message, a clue, anything.
Yes, Kapitan.
Captain Inna, you are becoming more trouble than you're worth...
Hiding, unless I miss my guess.
Funny.
It wasn't meant to be. These pirates are many things, Kapitan, but they are not stupid.
So what happens now?
You don't like waiting?
Not when we don't know where the enemy is. When combat starts I like it to be on my terms.
A luxury afforded by good intelligence and better fortune. The crew must be ready to do without both.
Not a big believer in luxuries, eh?
To each according to their contribution. Our victories are well earned, Kapitan. Never doubt that.
*ALARM*
And sometimes wishes do come true. Thanks, Chervona.
Thank the lookout. He's the one who raised the alarm.
Inna left a message behind, saying that they would return shortly.
That was... how long ago now?
Better late than never. I see her ship now... with Morganas in pursuit.
Intercept them.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Do we have any more incoming?
What is the condition of Captain Inna's ship?
Inna has a lot of explaining to do.

Fields.DialogueText: Not at the moment.
It appears damaged but seaworthy. As good as new, for our purposes.
I agree completely.
Send word to Captain Inna. I'll be going aboard her ship.
You do not wish to meet here?
No, I have had it with these games. I'm getting answers.
I have a feeling she had a different understanding of the word "shortly" than you or I.
*ALARM*
Sabotage?
That's what Captain Inna claims. Saboteurs within her ranks came after her, and she had to temporarily flee.
Kapitan, what good are these pirates? How can we expect them to help us when they're fighting amongst themselves?

Fields.MenuText: They have a knowledge of the region we don't.
They are capable sailors. We need capable people.
You may have a point, Chervona.

Fields.DialogueText: A knowledge that has not helped them recently.
There are many other capable sailors.
I know I have a point. The decision falls to you.
We will assist them for now. Leaving them like this is a death sentence.
Kapitan, if they choose not to unite against the greater threat--
Then we'll cut them loose. For now, Captain Inna said she will investigate her crew and report to us when she has more information.
*ALARM*
Until then, we are to provide cover.
I assumed as much. Ready for battle.
@BATTLE
Captain, Chervona, thank you for all you have done.
You're welcome, Inna.
Likewise. Why did you really want to meet?
I feel I can trust you. Both of you. I informed my crew I intend to accept your offer. We're family now, so I should tell you about the device.

Fields.MenuText: All things considered, I think our meeting has been fortunate.
The device?
We're not family, we're allies.

Fields.DialogueText: You said it, Captain.
I call it the device because I don't know what it is.
Label it how you want, but as far as I'm concerned, I'm your sister.
Why is the device so important?
*ALARM*
I'll must get back to the ship. Chervona, I can leave the details with you?
Kapitan?
I'll prepare for the Morganas. You two be quick about it.
Yes, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
A Morgana beacon?
That is how Inna described the device. According to her, it's capable of drawing in all Morganas from miles around.
But... but... ? Where did she get it?
She claims to have found it in a shipwreck.
*ALARM*
Well, I guess we now know how the Morganas ended up here.
We know more... and yet less.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: So, Inna activated the beacon after finding it.
I guess the pirates have more to offer than we thought.
I want that beacon here, now.

Fields.DialogueText: She didn't know what it was at the time.
They are surprising.
Inna may not honor that demand.
Send word to Captain Inna. I want to see her. Set up a rendezvous point some distance from the hideout.
At the center of a triangle, perhaps?
Very funny. We're a little more straightforward than that.
Exactly why we work so well together.
Why would the device be more secure in your hands? I didn't find it on a civilian shipwreck.
Captain, be reasonable. You have saboteurs within your ranks, a fleet in shambles, and are under constant threat of attack.
*ALARM*
Kapitan Inna, did you order half your ships to flee?
Of course not. Why?
They're fleeing. And we have Morganas headed in this direction. I'd say you're lucky to be in our hands.
@BATTLE
Filthy, good-for-nothing pirates!

Fields.MenuText: Inna, what happened?
Was the device on one of those ships?
This doesn't inspire confidence.

Fields.DialogueText: What does it look like? They mutinied!
Of course it was.
That's an understatement.
I'm heading back to a ship and pursuing. They must be heading back to the hideout.
How can you know?
Old Carl must have turned them. He blamed me for activating the beacon, and is convinced he's the man to defend the hideout from the Morganas.
We will regroup there, then, and prove him wrong.
You'd help those traitors?
They're fools, not fascists. Even they have a place in the world I know can be built.
Kapitan, I am troubled by the existence of this Morgana beacon.
I understand.
Do you? It is advanced, sophisticated. A navy developed this, not an individual.

Fields.MenuText: That does seem likely. What's your point?
Maybe it was a trap for the Morganas?
Why does it matter who made it?

Fields.DialogueText: I am fearful of their intentions.
It's possible, but there are other, more sinister possibilities.
Anyone mad enough to consort with the Morganas is more dangerous than the Morganas themselves.
You're worried it was to be used as a weapon?
There is still a war on land going on. Such a beacon could be used to target the Morganas toward a specific people group.
Don't worry, Chervona. I won't allow the beacon to fall into the wrong hands.
*ALARM*
We, Kapitan. We will stop it.
@BATTLE
Kapitan Inna is engaging the mutineers, but Morgana ships are incoming.
Bring us about. Captain Inna will handle her own business. Let's make sure she isn't interrupted.
Altering course.

Fields.MenuText: Can she win?
Keep an eye on their battle. We may need to help.
Do you think the mutineers can be convinced to return to her?

Fields.DialogueText: Her fleet outnumbers the mutineers. I like those odds.
Within our ability to do so, Kapitan. We hold together or fall together.
If they realize they're better served by working together, then perhaps.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
How is Captain Inna's battle going?
They've made it ashore, but the mutineers are dug in. It will be a siege.
In that case, there's nothing we can do. Why didn't she bombard from shore?
They're her family. She hopes some of them will come around.
Do you think they will?
Were I in her position, Kapitan... I would do the same. I would do the same until it became clear that I could not.
Here I thought you'd let them make their own mistakes.
There can be no revolution without unity, Kapitan... but that is not a choice that can be made for anyone. No matter how much you may want to make it.
And if they choose to fight you?
We win, and we mourn.
I must admit, Kapitan... this infighting is tiring.
Sometimes, but it's how people are.
It is not how they have to be.

Fields.MenuText: No, it isn't. But it comes naturally. And fighting that which comes naturally is difficult.
How do you know that?
It's human nature.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know how, but change must happen.
Because I have seen people who fight to protect each other, and not for personal gain.
It was once human nature to defecate anywhere, anytime.
Maybe we are on the way to being better. It just takes time.
This is how I feel, most of the time. However...
We are a lot like the Morganas, from a certain perspective.
Kapitan?
Well no, not all of us, but enough. They consume but will never quench their appetite for power, money, what have you.
How uplifting, Kapitan.
Sorry, I was just thinking out loud. The point was, eventually, the Morganas will one day cease to exist. A creature that's always hungry eventually starves.
Their nature will destroy them.
*ALARM*
Pick this up later?
There is much more we could say on who we are and what we're meant to be. Some of it I can at least demonstrate right now.
@BATTLE
If you Belles don't do it first.
And if our nature destroys us?
What nature is that? Mercy? Compassion? Protection?
Not all of my sisters suffer fools and malcontents as I do. But I admit... mercy can be frustrating.
Because you know what has to be done and you do it when the time is right.
Kapitan! Inna sends word: the mutineers are trying to activate the device. They think they can set the Morganas on Inna's ships!
That's insane!
Inna has launched a full assault to stop them.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: How many incoming, Chervona?
We need to buy time.
Prepare to join them.

Fields.DialogueText: A small detachment, but it may be a beginning.
All that our sweat can afford, Kapitan!
We won't let them down!
@BATTLE
Update?
None. Inna's group is still engaging the mutineers.
We would just get in the way on land. Our jurisdiction only extends so far.
It's her family, not ours.
Exactly. We've done our part with the Morganas. We have to trust Inna for now.
The device, it's active! They're coming!
Compose yourself, Captain. Is it on board?
I... Yes. I have it here. But...
Return to your ship. We'll take the beacon and draw them away.
Captain...
There is no time, Kapitan Inna. Please.
Of course. Thank you.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: Here they come.
This is a bad idea.
Get out of here, Inna!

Fields.DialogueText: We are battle ready, Kapitan.
Yes, but a good decision.
They're fleeing, Kapitan.
Let's punch through.
Yes, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Chervona, have you figured out how to turn off the beacon?
I am no scientist. If it were up to me I would have thrown the damn thing overboard and marked future charts "HERE THERE BE DRAGONS."
...Why didn't we do that in the first place?
Idealism, I suppose. Give the order.
I can take that paperwork for you, if you're done.
Paperwork is never done, Chervona. But yes, please, get it away from me.
Can I do anything for you?
I'm just curious - you won't be commissioning Inna and her crew?

Fields.MenuText: They need time to recover. They may be eager to fight, but they're not ready.
After what happened? Of course.
Yes, you were right about them all along.

Fields.DialogueText: That makes sense.
Understandable, but the blame does not all fall on Inna.
I don't know if that is true.
Do you disagree with my decision?
No, but I was surprised by Kapitan Inna in the end.
How so?
I saw her fight for family, for crew, not just for profit.
She did outshine her first impression.
As did you.
*ALARM*
I'm going to take that as a compliment.
Please do. Ready?
Engage.
@BATTLE
Chervona, we're moving a little fast, aren't we?
Hm? Oh - da.
We're heading back to port, so I thought I could afford to sprint.

Fields.MenuText: Ease up on the speed a little. What's the rush?
Excited about something?
Chervona, slow down.

Fields.DialogueText: I have mail, Kapitan!
Yes, Kapitan, very excited.
Yes, Kapitan, if that's an order.
Well? What's so exciting at port?
Stalin wrote me!
Who?
Don't be coy, Kapitan. Ioseb Besarionis dze Djugashvili himself. The General Secretary. The poet Soselo!
Ah...
I'm a huge fan. I've written so many letters, and he finally wrote back!
*ALARM*
What? Now?
Chervona.
Kapitan?
Break course and engage the Morganas.
At once.
When we're done, continue to port, full speed. You can tell me all about your letter later.
Yes, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Ready to depart?
As I'll ever be.
Good.
... So, as I was saying earlier...
Yes. It's not often you get a letter from the man in charge.
The things he's done for Ukraine... when I think of the future, I can't help but thrill at the idea.

Fields.MenuText: We make a good team, don't you think?

Fields.DialogueText: Possibly the best.

Fields.MenuText: You're good company and I wanted to learn more about you.

Fields.DialogueText: Only if I get to learn more about you too.
Do you need a moment to bask?
Ni... I have all of shore leave for that. Did you have something you wanted to say?
